cards.title: Brands: emojis, banter and hashtags are not for you
cards.rawTitle: Brands: emojis, banter and hashtags are not for you

item.title: Brands: emojis, banter and hashtags are not for you
item.trailText: It all began with Innocent smoothies ... and then along came social media. Tshepo Mokaena argues that corporate communication has taken a wrong turn
item.standFirst: It all began with Innocent smoothies ... and then along came social media. Tshepo Mokaena argues that corporate communication has taken a wrong turn – and asks whether it even works. From the rise of 'wackaging' – where companies use banter, slang and cheeky colloquialisms – to Domino's Pizza tweeting cat memes, brands should stop trying to be our friends
item.byline: Tshepo Mokoena, Maya Wolfe-Robinson, Leah Green, Caterina Monzani and Bruno Rinvolucri

cards.title: The wish list / Women's cross-body bags

item.title: Women's cross-body bags: the wish list
item.trailText: This season it’s all about the cross-body bag, a classic shape in an array of styles from quilted leather or colour block to suede or a tropical print
item.standFirst: This season it’s all about the cross-body bag, a classic shape in an array of styles from quilted leather or colour block to suede or a tropical print. This is the perfect bag to leave you hands-free on a busy day and it adds a touch of glamour to the simplest looks

cards.title: Rocks in the sky / A geological mystery

item.title: Rocks in the sky: a geological mystery
item.trailText: If you’ve never seen a huge boulder hovering above the Earth, where have you been? As David Quentin’s photographs show, they have be spotted everywhere from Cumbria to Québec
item.standFirst: If you’ve never seen a huge boulder hovering above the Earth against a brilliant blue sky, where have you been? As David Quentin’s photographs show, rocks in the sky have be spotted everywhere from Cumbria to Québec. Quentin’s photos aren’t fakes … but the rocks might not be quite what they seem

displayImages.caption:
Near Callanish, Isle of Lewis
‘I have been photographing rocks in the sky for five years. It started off as an attempt at a simple visual pun; I was walking on the South Downs and on a whim I threw a piece of chalk up into the sky to photograph it there because it was as white as a cloud. The photograph turned out pretty badly, and I became fascinated with the technical challenge of making photographs of rocks in the sky work.’

All photographs: David Quentin. The series was first published in issue 36 of Five Dials
displayImages.altText: Near Callanish, Isle Of Lewis
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Near Callanish, Isle of Lewis
‘I have been photographing rocks in the sky for five years. It started off as an attempt at a simple visual pun; I was walking on the South Downs and on a whim I threw a piece of chalk up into the sky to photograph it there because it was as white as a cloud. The photograph turned out pretty badly, and I became fascinated with the technical challenge of making photographs of rocks in the sky work.’

All photographs: David Quentin. The series was first published in issue 36 of Five Dials

displayImages.caption:
Nine Barrow Down, Isle of Purbeck
‘The process of taking them is quite dynamic. I have to move quickly for a number of reasons – to catch the light if it is changeable, to catch the right angle on the rock as it follows its trajectory across my viewfinder, and also so I don’t bore whoever I am with, since these photographs are always taken while I am on a walk with a friend. The resulting photographs, by contrast, always seem serene and static. I am not sure they reflect the process that has created them. They reflect something else altogether.’
displayImages.altText: Nine Barrow Down, Isle Of Purbeck
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Nine Barrow Down, Isle of Purbeck
‘The process of taking them is quite dynamic. I have to move quickly for a number of reasons – to catch the light if it is changeable, to catch the right angle on the rock as it follows its trajectory across my viewfinder, and also so I don’t bore whoever I am with, since these photographs are always taken while I am on a walk with a friend. The resulting photographs, by contrast, always seem serene and static. I am not sure they reflect the process that has created them. They reflect something else altogether.’

displayImages.caption:
Brent crater, Ontario
‘Sometimes I throw them; sometimes I ask a friend to throw the rock (one such rock-throwing collaborator is author Robert Macfarlane). If I do it myself it is just a matter of throwing with my left hand, while I hold the camera to my eye and take the picture with my right hand. I do not use a tripod, as I need to move while the rock is moving to frame it properly.’
displayImages.altText: Brent Crater, Ontario
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Brent crater, Ontario
‘Sometimes I throw them; sometimes I ask a friend to throw the rock (one such rock-throwing collaborator is author Robert Macfarlane). If I do it myself it is just a matter of throwing with my left hand, while I hold the camera to my eye and take the picture with my right hand. I do not use a tripod, as I need to move while the rock is moving to frame it properly.’

displayImages.caption:
Watendlath Fell, Cumbria
‘The rocks look to me like they are hanging there, “in much the same way that bricks don’t”, as Douglas Adams wrote.’
displayImages.altText: Watendlath Fell, Cumbria
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Watendlath Fell, Cumbria
‘The rocks look to me like they are hanging there, “in much the same way that bricks don’t”, as Douglas Adams wrote.’

displayImages.caption:
Seilebost beach, Harris
‘It’s hard to choose my favourite. The one on Seilebost Beach has a deliciously sinister and otherworldly feel. The geology is so interesting there, and the colours so pretty. The one with the “falling rocks” warning sign still amuses me, even though the joke is very obvious. And I love the fact that it features a piece of mind-blowingly ancient Lewisian Gneiss, one of the most celebrated and fascinating rock types in the British Isles.’
displayImages.altText: Seilebost Beach, Harris
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Seilebost beach, Harris
‘It’s hard to choose my favourite. The one on Seilebost Beach has a deliciously sinister and otherworldly feel. The geology is so interesting there, and the colours so pretty. The one with the “falling rocks” warning sign still amuses me, even though the joke is very obvious. And I love the fact that it features a piece of mind-blowingly ancient Lewisian Gneiss, one of the most celebrated and fascinating rock types in the British Isles.’

displayImages.caption:
Charlevoix crater, Québec
‘Geology is a snapshot of a dynamic process, and part of that dynamism derives from the buoyancy of different rock types. To that extent, my photographs seem to me to be a kind of extreme geology.’
displayImages.altText: Charlevoix Crater, Quebec
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Charlevoix crater, Québec
‘Geology is a snapshot of a dynamic process, and part of that dynamism derives from the buoyancy of different rock types. To that extent, my photographs seem to me to be a kind of extreme geology.’

cards.title: Caitlyn Jenner / A pivotal moment for trans people
cards.rawTitle: A pivotal moment for trans people

item.title: Caitlyn Jenner cover a ‘pivotal moment for trans people’
item.trailText: Former Olympic decathlon gold-medallist Caitlyn Jenner, previously known as Bruce Jenner, is praised by the Los Angeles LGBT community for her debut in Vanity Fair
item.standFirst: Former Olympic decathlon gold-medallist Caitlyn Jenner, previously known as Bruce Jenner, is praised by the Los Angeles LGBT community for her debut in Vanity Fair. Drian Juarez, a program manager at the Los Angeles LGBT Center, calls the cover a 'pivotal moment' for trans people, and says Jenner is helping to change the way transgender people are written about and depicted in the media

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Caitlyn Jenner Photograph: guardian.co.uk

displayImages.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Caitlyn Jenner Photograph: guardian.co.uk
displayImages.altText: 620x372 trailpic for Caitlyn Jenner

cards.title: Pull up the drawbridge / Homes with moats

item.title: Homes with moats
item.trailText: If you feel the need to pull up the drawbridge, or if you just like being surrounded by water, here are some homes to whet your appetite
item.standFirst: If you feel the need to pull up the drawbridge, or if you just like being surrounded by water, here are some homes to whet your appetite

displayImages.caption:
Home: Brentwood, Essex
Water is a dominant theme in this five-bedroom farmhouse for beyond the wide moat is a swimming pool complex with a whirlpool bath. It’s shielded from the urban sprawl by 22 private acres including a floodlit menage, stabling, croquet lawn and vaulted brew house, but rail links and the nearby M25 whisk you to metropolitan stimulants. Guide price: £2.15m.
Hetheringtons, 01277 724 705
displayImages.altText: H&A0306: Brentwood
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Home: Brentwood, Essex
Water is a dominant theme in this five-bedroom farmhouse for beyond the wide moat is a swimming pool complex with a whirlpool bath. It’s shielded from the urban sprawl by 22 private acres including a floodlit menage, stabling, croquet lawn and vaulted brew house, but rail links and the nearby M25 whisk you to metropolitan stimulants. Guide price: £2.15m.
Hetheringtons, 01277 724 705

displayImages.caption:
Home: Broughton, near Aylesbury, Buckinghamshire
You have to cross a wooden bridge to reach the front door of this 600-year-old former hall house and another one to access the back garden. There are five bedrooms dwarfed by the stately main bathroom, a study and three beamed receptions, one dominated by a 17th century inglenook. For £1.1m the 2.2 acres include a paddock with a stream and an outbuilding begging for conversion.
John D Wood, 01865 575 179
displayImages.altText: H&A0306: Broughton
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Home: Broughton, near Aylesbury, Buckinghamshire
You have to cross a wooden bridge to reach the front door of this 600-year-old former hall house and another one to access the back garden. There are five bedrooms dwarfed by the stately main bathroom, a study and three beamed receptions, one dominated by a 17th century inglenook. For £1.1m the 2.2 acres include a paddock with a stream and an outbuilding begging for conversion.
John D Wood, 01865 575 179

displayImages.caption:
Home: Whites Hill, Sulhamstead, Berkshire
The moated site of this 400-year-old cottage and its two medieval fish ponds have been listed as Ancient Monuments by English Heritage. All have now been breached for drainage but could easily be refilled. With a guide price of £550,000, they lie within a bluebell wood in the 1.66 acres of grounds and a well that used to water the household. The planners have agreed to a glass-walled extension across the back to create a new living room, kitchen and third bedroom with an en suite.
Singleton & Daughter, 0118 984 2662
displayImages.altText: H&A0306: Sulhamstead
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Home: Whites Hill, Sulhamstead, Berkshire
The moated site of this 400-year-old cottage and its two medieval fish ponds have been listed as Ancient Monuments by English Heritage. All have now been breached for drainage but could easily be refilled. With a guide price of £550,000, they lie within a bluebell wood in the 1.66 acres of grounds and a well that used to water the household. The planners have agreed to a glass-walled extension across the back to create a new living room, kitchen and third bedroom with an en suite.
Singleton & Daughter, 0118 984 2662

displayImages.caption:
Home: Brundish, Suffolk
The Georgians extended this five-bedroom Tudor farmhouse and the vendor has added a drawing room and guest suite, but progress has left alone the surrounding moat which separates the formal gardens from an orchard, meadows and an ancient rose garden. Barns and outbuildings could be harnessed for household expansion subject to planning permission. Guide price: £895,000.
Bedfords, 01394 779 444
displayImages.altText: H&A0306: Brundish
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Home: Brundish, Suffolk
The Georgians extended this five-bedroom Tudor farmhouse and the vendor has added a drawing room and guest suite, but progress has left alone the surrounding moat which separates the formal gardens from an orchard, meadows and an ancient rose garden. Barns and outbuildings could be harnessed for household expansion subject to planning permission. Guide price: £895,000.
Bedfords, 01394 779 444

displayImages.caption:
Away: near Isernia, Molise, Italy
This medieval fortress was built on a crag above the river Carpino. Impregnable on three sides the only access is via a drawbridge over the moat. The old dungeons, guardrooms and chapel are usefully intact, but the entirety requires renovation to embrace modern living standards. The result will be 1,024 sq metres of dramatic accommodation plus numerous outbuildings with sweeping views over the mountainscape. €1m (£719,250).
Italian Houses Real Estate, +39 366 629 0173
displayImages.altText: H&A0306: Molise
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Away: near Isernia, Molise, Italy
This medieval fortress was built on a crag above the river Carpino. Impregnable on three sides the only access is via a drawbridge over the moat. The old dungeons, guardrooms and chapel are usefully intact, but the entirety requires renovation to embrace modern living standards. The result will be 1,024 sq metres of dramatic accommodation plus numerous outbuildings with sweeping views over the mountainscape. €1m (£719,250).

cards.title: TV Times’s unseen portraits of celebrities
cards.rawTitle: TV Times’s unseen portraits of celebrities

item.title: TV Times's unseen portraits of celebrities
item.trailText: Previously unseen and undated images of Ronnie Barker, Liza Minnelli and Woody Allen have been released after they were unearthed in an archive
item.standFirst: Previously unseen and undated images of Ronnie Barker, Liza Minnelli and Woody Allen have been released after they were unearthed in an archive. The TV Times images were found in A4 envelopes packed up inside boxes at the British Film Institute (BFI) in London, after being stored there for more than 50 years. Only a tiny fraction were published before they were stashed away

cards.title: Atkins Ciwem / Environmental photographer of the year

item.title: Atkins Ciwem environmental photographer of the year 2015
item.trailText: From 22 June to 10 July the Royal Geographical Society in London will exhibit 111 outstanding images, selected from over 10,000 submitted by photographers and filmmakers from 60 countries for the competition organised by the Chartered Institution of Water and Environmental Management (Ciwem), and sponsored by Atkins. Winners will be announced on 25 June. Here is a selection of some of the best from the shortlist
item.standFirst: From 22 June to 10 July the Royal Geographical Society in London will exhibit 111 outstanding images, selected from over 10,000 submitted by photographers and filmmakers from 60 countries for the competition organised by the Chartered Institution of Water and Environmental Management (Ciwem), and sponsored by Atkins. Winners will be announced on 25 June. Here is a selection of some of the best from the shortlist

displayImages.caption: Checking fishing net by Hoang Long Ly, Vietnam. Photograph: Hoang Long Ly /Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.credit: Hoang Long Ly /Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.altText: Fishing net checking by Hoang Long Ly (Vietnam)
displayImages.cleanCaption: Checking fishing net by Hoang Long Ly, Vietnam.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Hoang Long Ly /Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year

displayImages.caption: Glacier 1987 by Simon Norfolk, Mount Kenya. The flame line shows the Lewis Glacier’s location in 1987. The glacier has since receded by about 120 metres. In 1987 the Curling Pond seen in the image was 15m higher than seen presently and it had a tall wall of ice – the glacier’s snout – forming its back wall. The rounded peak is Point Thomson. Photograph: Simon Norfolk/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.credit: Simon Norfolk/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.altText: Glacier 1987 by Simon Norfolk, Mount Kenya, 2014 1987 Climate change and the melting of the Lewis Glacier on Mount Kenya.The flame line shows the Lewis Glacier's location in 1987.The glacier has since receded about 120m. The pond is called the Curling Pond. In 1987 it's surface was 15m higher than presently and the back wall of the pond was a tall wall of ice - the glacier's snout.The  rounded peak is Point Thomson
displayImages.cleanCaption: Glacier 1987 by Simon Norfolk, Mount Kenya. The flame line shows the Lewis Glacier’s location in 1987. The glacier has since receded by about 120 metres. In 1987 the Curling Pond seen in the image was 15m higher than seen presently and it had a tall wall of ice – the glacier’s snout – forming its back wall. The rounded peak is Point Thomson.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Simon Norfolk/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year

displayImages.caption: Collecting crabs by Kazi Riasat Alve, Satkhira, Bangladesh. High salinity has rendered the land unsuitable for farming. Photograph: Kazi Riasat Alve/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.credit: Kazi Riasat Alve/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.altText: Collecting crabs by Kazi Riasat Alve, Satkhira 2014
displayImages.cleanCaption: Collecting crabs by Kazi Riasat Alve, Satkhira, Bangladesh. High salinity has rendered the land unsuitable for farming.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Kazi Riasat Alve/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year

displayImages.caption: Life in tidal flood 3 by Jashim Salam , Chittagong, Bangladesh. A family watches TV in their flooded house after a tidal flood in Chittagong. Rising sea level has begun to affect 6.5 million people living in Chittagong. Flooding of residential and business areas is common and most of the city could completely submerge as climate change keeps pushing the sea level up. Photograph: Jashim Salam/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.credit: Jashim Salam/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.altText: Life in tidal flood 3 by Jashim Salam , Chittagong, Bangladesh , 2014. A family watching TV in an inundated house and waits for water to recede during a tidal flood in Chittagong.In the past few years, Tidal surge     sea levels rising significantly has begun to affect the Chittagong city estimated population of 6.5 million, resulting in frequent flooding of residential and business areas.If things continue to worsen, most area of Chittagong could become completely submerged in the near future and million will be climate refugee.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Life in tidal flood 3 by Jashim Salam , Chittagong, Bangladesh. A family watches TV in their flooded house after a tidal flood in Chittagong. Rising sea level has begun to affect 6.5 million people living in Chittagong. Flooding of residential and business areas is common and most of the city could completely submerge as climate change keeps pushing the sea level up.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Jashim Salam/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year

displayImages.caption: Barber shop 2 by Hayri Kodal, Turkey 2011. Photograph: Hayri Kodal/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.credit: Hayri Kodal/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.altText: Berber 2 by Hayri Kodal, Turkey 2011
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Hayri Kodal/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year

displayImages.caption: Cladonia forest by Matthew Cicanese, USA. Photograph: Matthew Cicanese/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.credit: Matthew Cicanese/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.altText: Cladonia forest by Matthew Cicanese, USA, 2014
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Matthew Cicanese/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year

displayImages.caption: The Devil’s gold by Luca Catalano Gonzaga, Indonesia. Alpan, 27, a sulphur miner for 10 years, looks for sulphur slabs under the toxic fumes. Inside the womb of the Ijen Kawah volcano, in eastern Java, Indonesia, the miners go deep in search of the Devil’s gold, as sulphur has always been known. Photograph: Luca Catalano Gonzaga/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.credit: Luca Catalano Gonzaga/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.altText: The Devil’s gold by Luca Catalano Gonzaga, Indonesia 2014. Alpan, 27, a sulfur miner for ten years now, looks for sulfur slabs under the toxic fumes.Inside the womb of the Ijen Kawah volcano, in Eastern Java, Indonesia, the miners go deep in search of the Devil's gold, as sulfur has always been known.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The Devil’s gold by Luca Catalano Gonzaga, Indonesia. Alpan, 27, a sulphur miner for 10 years, looks for sulphur slabs under the toxic fumes. Inside the womb of the Ijen Kawah volcano, in eastern Java, Indonesia, the miners go deep in search of the Devil’s gold, as sulphur has always been known.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Luca Catalano Gonzaga/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year

displayImages.caption: Plastic tree #20 by Eduardo Leal, Bolivia. Plastic bags are part of the landscape in the Bolivian Altiplano. The accumulation of plastic bags cause deterioration of the landscapes and agriculture soils and it is associated to the death of domestic and wild animals. Photograph: Eduardo Leal/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.credit: Eduardo Leal/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.altText: Plastic tree #20 by Eduardo Leal, Bolivia, 2014. Plastic bags are part of the landscape in the Bolivian Altiplano. The accumulation of plastic bags on the environment cause deterioration of the landscapes and agriculture soils and it is associated to the death of domestic and wild animals.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Plastic tree #20 by Eduardo Leal, Bolivia. Plastic bags are part of the landscape in the Bolivian Altiplano. The accumulation of plastic bags cause deterioration of the landscapes and agriculture soils and it is associated to the death of domestic and wild animals.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Eduardo Leal/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year

displayImages.caption: Sandstorm in the city by Rizalde Cayanan, Kuwait. Photograph: Rizalde Cayanan/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.credit: Rizalde Cayanan/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.altText: Sandstorm in the city by Rizalde Cayanan , Kuwait, 2011.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Sandstorm in the city by Rizalde Cayanan, Kuwait.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Rizalde Cayanan/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year

displayImages.caption: Retrace our steps by Carlos Ayesta and Guillaume Bression, Fukushima, Japan. Staged image of a former worker in the now derelict supermarket returning to see its remains following the Fukushima disaster. Photograph: Carlos Ayesta and Guillaume Bression/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.credit: Carlos Ayesta and Guillaume Bression/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.altText: Retrace our steps by Carlos Ayesta and Guillaume Bression, Fukushima 2014  Staged image of a former worker in the now derelict supermarket returning to see its remains following the Fukushima disaster, Japan
displayImages.cleanCaption: Retrace our steps by Carlos Ayesta and Guillaume Bression, Fukushima, Japan. Staged image of a former worker in the now derelict supermarket returning to see its remains following the Fukushima disaster.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Carlos Ayesta and Guillaume Bression/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year

displayImages.caption: Beauty salon by Petrut Calinescu, Lagos, Nigeria. Two women, dressed in purple and holding weaves, stand in the doorway of a hair and beauty saloon, one of several such waterside establishments in Makoko. They are usually very busy on Sunday, when the women of the local community are preparing for church or other ceremonies. The Makoko slum is a community, under threat from eviction, built over the polluted waters of the Lagos Lagoon. Photograph: Petrut Calinescu/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.credit: Petrut Calinescu/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.altText: Beauty Salon by Petrut Calinescu, Lagos, Nigeria 2014. Two women, dressed in purple and holding weaves, stand in the doorway of a hair and beauty saloon, one of several such waterside establishments in Makoko. They are usually very busy on Sunday, when the women of the local community are preparing for church or other ceremonies. The Makoko slum is a community, under threat from eviction, built over the polluted waters of the Lagos Lagoon.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Beauty salon by Petrut Calinescu, Lagos, Nigeria. Two women, dressed in purple and holding weaves, stand in the doorway of a hair and beauty saloon, one of several such waterside establishments in Makoko. They are usually very busy on Sunday, when the women of the local community are preparing for church or other ceremonies. The Makoko slum is a community, under threat from eviction, built over the polluted waters of the Lagos Lagoon.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Petrut Calinescu/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year

displayImages.caption: The abandoned village of Geamana by Glyn Thomas, Romania. Geamana in the Carpathian Mountains in Romania – an abandoned village in what is now a toxic tailings pond from a nearby copper mine. Photograph: Glyn Thomas/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.credit: Glyn Thomas/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
displayImages.altText: The abandoned village of Geamana by Glyn Thomas, Romania, 2014. Geamana in the Carpathian Mountains in Romania - an abandoned village in what is now a toxic tailings pond from a nearby copper mine.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The abandoned village of Geamana by Glyn Thomas, Romania. Geamana in the Carpathian Mountains in Romania – an abandoned village in what is now a toxic tailings pond from a nearby copper mine.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Glyn Thomas/Courtesy of Atkins CIWEM Environmental Photographer of the Year
